results.title: My Brilliant Career paperback
results.brief_description: My Brilliant Career, adapted from Stella Miles Franklin’s 1901 novel of the same name, was Gillian Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

constellations_primary.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_primary.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

results.description: Paperback book ‘My Brilliant Career’, with soft cover and the title written on front in red ‘My Brilliant Career’, on a black background and in white text authors name ‘Miles Franklin’.
description_for_label: Paperback book ‘My Brilliant Career’, with soft cover and the title written on front in red ‘My Brilliant Career’, on a black background and in white text authors name ‘Miles Franklin’.

results.title: Stereoscopic Images and Box for Tin Folding Stereoviewer (PRESERVATION)
results.material_description: black and white stereoscopic image on card
results.brief_description:
TO BE KEPT FOR PRESERVATION OF AEO180821 TIN VIEWER AND P182175 11 IMAGES FOR DISPLAY

Vintage tin toy Stereo Viewer Imperial. Good Condition. with 26 Original Stereo Views in original box. Patent (D.R.G.M.) No 157580. Often referred to as a rotograph or rotoscope.

Text on viewer (in German): “Imperial / Neue photographische gesellschaft / Aktiengesellschaf / Stieglitz/
D.R.G.M. (Patent) No.157580 /
Fur diesen apparat /
sind /
passende BILDER /
von LANDSCHAFTEN /
stets vorhanden /
weitere /
erganzung derselben /
in vorbereitung”

results.title: Stereoscop apparat imperial (Stereoscopic apparatus)
results.brief_description:
Vintage tin toy Stereo Viewer Imperial. Good Condition. with 26 Original Stereo Views in original box. Patent (D.R.G.M.) No 157580. Often referred to as a rotograph or rotoscope.

Text on viewer (in German): “Imperial / Neue photographische gesellschaft / Aktiengesellschaf / Stieglitz/
D.R.G.M. (Patent) No.157580 /
Fur diesen apparat /
sind /
passende BILDER /
von LANDSCHAFTEN /
stets vorhanden /
weitere /
erganzung derselben /
in vorbereitung”
results.description:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
description_for_label:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
